channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Seeing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
item.description: Western leaders, including President Biden, Boris Johnson and Emmanuel Macron, sought to capitalize on Russia’s apparent lack of battlefield momentum to show Ukraine support and strengthen its resolve, and its arsenal.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees from the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol arriving in Zaporizhzhia on Tuesday, after spending weeks sheltering in the bunkers underneath the industrial complex.

item.title: Israel Plans Zip Line for Ancient Jerusalem
item.description: A Jewish settler group is promoting projects that opponents say will change the delicate historic, religious and political balance in highly symbolic areas around Jerusalem’s Old City.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palestinian neighborhood of Silwan in East Jerusalem below the Old City walls. Known as the holy basin, the area around the ramparts is dotted with archaeological ruins and shrines of the major monotheistic religions.

item.title: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
item.description: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rescue worker on an upper floor of an apartment building hit by a Russian missile strike in central Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Cuban Migrants Arrive to U.S. in Record Numbers, on Foot, Not by Boat
item.description: Political repression and escalating economic difficulties on the island, along with a new visa-free travel policy in Nicaragua, are some of the factors driving the change.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: Yaquemile, a migrant from Cuba, wading through the Rio Grande from Mexico into Texas in April.

item.title: They Fell Deeply in Love in Bucha. One Russian Bullet Ended It All.
item.description: Over nearly two decades, Iryna Abramova and her husband, Oleh, built a life of love and happiness. Now, she says, she wishes the Russian soldiers had shot her, too.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna Abramova at the grave of her husband, Oleh Abramov, who was killed by Russian forces outside their home in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Cheap Dining Options Are All the Rage
item.description: In a city pummeled by political upheaval, economic downturn and the pandemic, bare-bones ‘two dishes and rice’ restaurants have become a go-to destination across all social classes.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line outside a “two dishes and rice” restaurant in the Sham Shui Po area of Hong Kong in February.

item.title: Australian Gets 12 Years for Anti-Gay Killing of an American in 1988
item.description: Scott Johnson, a U.S. graduate student, was pushed off a cliff, in a case that was first ruled a suicide but that his brother refused to let go of.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:description: Steve Johnson with his sisters, Terry and Rebecca, and his wife, Rosemarie, second from right, while arriving at the Supreme Court in Sydney, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: In Kyiv, Residents Cautiously Embrace a Sense of Normalcy
item.description: A month after the Ukrainian Army defeated the Russian forces that had partly encircled Ukraine’s capital, tension is slowly seeping out of the city.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Kyiv residents gathered outside a bar in the center of the city on Saturday. Ukrainians have been returning to the capital, and life in the city seems to be regaining some normalcy.

item.title: Bangladesh Shutters Dozens of Schools Set Up by Rohingya in Camps
item.description: More than 30 schools, teaching tens of thousands of Rohingya students, were closed in Bangladesh, where officials are said to have feared the schools would encourage the refugees to stay permanently.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Sameer Yasir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Fabeha Monir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kayaphuri High School, where about 600 Rohingya students were enrolled, was the largest of the community-run schools shut down by the Bangladesh government.

item.title: For an organist from Kharkiv, a performance is ‘a prayer’ in a time of despair.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Playing the organ for me is vital,” the Ukrainian musician Stanislav Kalinin said. “I can’t live and not play, it’s like breathing for me. Playing here after the Kharkiv silence gives me back this feeling of life.”

item.title: Spain Says Cellphones of Prime Minister and Defense Minister Were Hacked
item.description: Officials said the devices were breached by the Pegasus spyware, made by an Israeli company, which is intended to track illegal behavior but has been misused by some governments.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain, left, and Defense Minister Margarita Robles in 2019.

item.title: Inside China’s Zero-Covid Fortress, Xi Jinping Admits No Doubts
item.description: As the lockdown of Shanghai and outbreaks in Beijing and elsewhere batter the economy, China’s leader keeps a distance from the politically charged issue.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A worker registering for a Covid test on Thursday in Beijing, where lockdowns so far have targeted individual buildings or streets, unlike in Shanghai.

item.title: Ahead of Philippines Election, Young People Rally Around Leni Robredo
item.description: As the election in the Philippines nears, tens of thousands of young people who fear another Marcos presidency are rallying around Leni Robredo, the country’s vice president.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for Leni Robredo in early April in Pampanga, the Philippines. Ms. Robredo, the country’s vice president, is polling a distant second in the presidential race.

item.title: She Promised to Empower Women. Will Honduras’s President Succeed?
item.description: The country’s first female leader, Xiomara Castro, is struggling to advance her feminist agenda 14 years after a coup ended the presidency of her husband, who pursued similar causes.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Joan Suazo
item.media:description: President Xiomara Castro during her inauguration ceremony in January in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

item.title: Sensing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
item.description: ‘You have exploded the myth of Putin’s invincibility,’ Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers, one of several Western sources of cheerleading on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Jason Horowitz
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: President Biden greeting employees at a Lockheed Martin facility that makes weapon systems including Javelin anti-tank missiles, on Tuesday in Troy, Ala.

item.title: Britain’s Parliament Is Rocked by Sexist Episodes. Again.
item.description: Encouraging more women to run for office, critics say, is just one way to counter pervasive misogyny and sexual harassment in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Palace of Westminster, Britain’s seat of Parliament, in London.

item.title: Russian Missiles Hit Power Stations in Lviv and Along Crucial Railways
item.description: Altogether, six electrical substations were struck along the railways in central and western Ukraine, according to a top rail official. The rail system is the country’s lifeline for humanitarian and military supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising from the site of a Russian missile attack in the western city of Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday evening.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The End of Roe?
item.description: Abortion is in jeopardy in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights advocates surrounded anti-abortion activists in front of the Supreme Court yesterday.

item.title: Biden Visits an Alabama Missile Factory, Highlighting Aid to Ukraine
item.description: “You are making it possible for the Ukrainian people to defend themselves” without “sending American soldiers to fight Russian soldiers,” which would risk world war, the president said.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and John Ismay
item.media:description: President Biden touring a Lockheed Martin plant that manufactures Javelin antitank missiles in Troy, Ala., on Tuesday.

item.title: Beijing Tightens Measures as Some Residents Grow Weary
item.description: Authorities are trying to avoid a lockdown like the one imposed in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
item.media:description: Disinfectant being sprayed outside a restaurant after the government banned dine-in service in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: 6 Podcasts That Go Deeper on the Headlines
item.description: These series, on subjects like the war in Ukraine, the storming of the U.S. Capitol and the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, can help combat news fatigue.
item.dc:creator: Emma Dibdin

item.title: Evacuees From Mariupol’s Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
item.description: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Almost 130 evacuees from Mariupol arrived in Zaporizhzhia, in southeastern Ukraine, on Tuesday after spending weeks hiding in bunkers underneath the Azovstal steel plant.

item.title: Smithsonian Adopts Policy on Ethical Returns in a Nod to Changing Norms
item.description: The institution’s leaders hope other cultural centers will follow its lead. It has already announced plans to return most of its collection of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria under the new policy.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: The Smithsonian Instititution has adopted a policy that makes clear its committment to return items from its collection that it determines were looted or had been otherwise acquired unethically.

item.title: Boris Johnson Calls Russia War ‘Ukraine’s Finest Hour’
item.description: In the first address by a foreign leader to Ukraine’s Parliament, Britain’s prime minister burnished his credentials as a supporter of the resistance to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain addressing Ukrainian lawmakers via videolink, in Kyiv, on Tuesday.

item.title: Roe, on the Edge
item.description: Roe v. Wade seems to be on the cusp of falling.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at the Supreme Court.

item.title: What Sanctions Have Been Imposed on Russia?
item.description: Our reporters answer readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you asked about economic penalties and how Putin could respond.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The Russian oil producer Gazprom Neft's oil refinery on the outskirts of Moscow in April.

item.title: To Save Water Amid a Megadrought, Las Vegas Outlaws Grass
item.description: With drought and growth taking a toll on the Colorado River, the source of 90 percent of the region’s water, a new law in Las Vegas mandates the removal of turf, patch by patch.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Joe Buglewicz

item.title: Colorado River Reservoirs Are So Low, Government Will Delay Releases
item.description: The decision will keep more water in Lake Powell on the Arizona-Utah border, instead of releasing it downstream to Lake Mead. Both reservoirs are at their lowest points.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Lake Powell at the Glen Canyon Dam in northern Arizona, where water levels are at their lowest point since the lake was filled in the 1960s.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An evacuation from Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelena Safonova, right, with her husband, Sergey, and their daughter, Ksenia, after fleeing from Mariupol to Zaporizhzhia.

item.title: Painful Stories Emerge From Mariupol, While Combat Rages to the East
item.description: With its forces making only slow progress and enduring heavy losses, Russia now plans to annex eastern parts of Ukraine after a sham election, the U.S. says.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family from the Russian-occupied city of Mariupol arriving on Monday in Zaporizhzhia in southeast Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Plans to Annex Parts of Ukraine with ‘Sham’ Elections, U.S. Diplomat Says
item.description: The official said that Russia may also try to take over parts of Ukraine by imposing “puppets and proxies” in local governments and forcing out democratically elected officials.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: The head of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic, Denis Pushilin, left, with members of the Russian military and the newly-appointed mayor of the city of Mariupol, Konstantin Ivashchenko, speaking with a resident of Mariupol last week.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Beijing’s Fight against Lockdowns
item.description: And Mariupol evacuees start to emerge.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Weeks of confinement in Shanghai have fueled anger and anxiety about the cost of a “zero-Covid” strategy.

item.title: Italy eases mask and health-pass rules for bars, restaurants and shops.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: A bar in Rome on Sunday. Italian health authorities have dropped masking requirements for restaurants, bars and shops.

item.title: Pelosi Says Russia’s War Merits the Strongest Military Response and Sanctions
item.description: Following a visit to Kyiv over the weekend, Speaker Nancy Pelosi held talks in Poland with President Andrzej Duda, a meeting aimed at deepening Washington’s partnership with a key NATO ally.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi met with President Andrzej Duda of Poland and other officials in Warsaw on Monday.

item.title: Israel Condemns Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov’s Comments as Antisemitic
item.description: Israel’s response is among the fiercest criticism it has leveled at the Russian government since the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Myra Noveck
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, said he thought that Hitler had Jewish roots, a claim dismissed by historians.

item.title: Learning More
item.description: Why did U.S. schools make so much progress in the 1990s and early 2000s?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reading and math skills improved for students, since the 90s.

item.title: Beijing Reopens Mass Isolation Center In Attempt to Avoid Broad Lockdown
item.description: While the Chinese capital has recorded only a few hundred cases in recent weeks, the move to reopen the facility appears to be aimed at avoiding the fate of Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
item.media:description: Workers disinfecting a bed in the Xiaotangshan hospital in Beijing in April 2020.

item.title: Sisters Recount Escape From Mariupol as Russians Closed In
item.description: The women say they were forced onto a bus to Russian-controlled territory, then escaped what Ukrainian and U.S. officials have described as “filtration” centers for a system of forced expulsions to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vera, left, and her sister, Nicole, flank Vera’s son, Kirill, in Kyiv, Ukraine, after fleeing Russian-controlled territory.

item.title: South Africa’s latest surge is a possible preview of the pandemic’s next chapter.
item.description: The spread of two newly discovered subvariants has doctors watching closely.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: A mural in Katlehong, South Africa, east of Johannesburg, last week. South Africa has likely entered a new wave of Covid-19, earlier than expected.

item.title: U.K. Plan to Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda Stokes Anger and Dread
item.description: The government’s proposal has led to recriminations from rights groups, and anxiety among migrants who fear being sent away.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Folkestone, in Kent, southeastern England, has become a temporary waypoint for asylum seekers awaiting decisions on their applications.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia tries to gain ground in Ukraine’s east.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Russian Tycoon Criticized Putin’s War. Retribution Was Swift.
item.description: Oleg Tinkov spoke out against his country’s war in Ukraine. Now he is in hiding. In an exclusive interview he said, “I don’t believe in Russia’s future’’ under Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Oleg Tinkov in St. Petersburg in 2019.

item.title: Pelosi Visit to Ukraine Signals Growing U.S. Resolve Against Russia
item.description: In Mariupol, the scene of intense fighting, civilians who had taken refuge at a steel plant were at least able to begin evacuating.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Jane Arraf and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dariia Piven, 33, visiting the grave of her parents in Irpin, Ukraine, on Sunday. They were shot in March by Russian soldiers, she said.

item.title: U.S. and Ukraine Officials: Top Russian Officer Went to War’s Frontline
item.description: The presence of such a high-ranking official on the front lines is highly unusual and comes amid what Western military analysts describe as increasing disarray within Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Gen. Valery Gerasimov, chief of the general staff of the Russian military, in Moscow, Russia, in December.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Pelosi Visits Ukraine
item.description: Plus Xi remains quiet on Covid lockdowns and young Filipinos rally for a long shot candidate.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Régine, Whose Discotheque Gave Nightlife a New Dawn, Dies at 92
item.description: Credited with opening the first disco, she built an empire of glittering playgrounds for the Beautiful People in Paris, New York and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Régine in 1972. She built a $500 million empire of 23 clubs in Europe, the Middle East and the Americas, including Régine’s in Manhattan, the most famous nightspot of its era.

item.title: ISIS Launches Bloody New Chapter in Afghanistan
item.description: At least 100 people have died in terrorist attacks over the past two weeks, as the Islamic State targets minorities in Afghanistan and aims to undermine the Taliban government.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boys’ school in Kabul that was bombed last month.

item.title: The ‘Ghost of Kyiv’ Is a Myth, Ukraine Acknowledges
item.description: The legend of a pilot who shot down numerous Russian aircraft was one of the more successful pieces of propaganda in Ukraine’s information war.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pieces of a downed aircraft in a Kyiv neighborhood in February.

item.title: In Egypt’s Big Ramadan TV Drama ‘The Choice’, the President Is the Hero
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi says “The Choice” tells the truth about his rise. Critics say it’s a rewriting of recent history from an industry increasingly cowed under his rule.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A billboard in Cairo promotes “The Choice 3,” a Ramadan television series about President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s rise to power.

item.title: 100 Civilians Evacuated From Mariupol Steel Factory, Officials Say
item.description: The Ukrainian president said that civilians were being evacuated from the Azovstal steel factory and are headed to a “controlled area.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: Evacuees, including civilians who left the area near the steel plant in Mariupol, arrive in the Donetsk Region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi and Democratic Lawmakers Say U.S. Will Support Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi with a congressional delegation at a news conference on Sunday in Rzeszow, Poland.

item.title: A Grim Existence
item.description: Many Ukrainians are in mobilization mode.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentina Mutyeva, 72, sits by candlelight and flashlight in a basement shelter where she has been living under a residential building for a month under constant shelling in the village of Avdiivka in Eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Beijing Escalates Restrictions After Covid Outbreak, but No Full Lockdown
item.description: Officials in China’s capital are striving to contain a coronavirus outbreak while avoiding public anger of the kind that has erupted in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Workers in protective suits on Sunday in one of Beijing’s most affluent districts, Chaoyang, where many of the recent coronavirus cases have been detected.

item.title: Deaths of Foreign Fighters Renew Attention on Ukraine War Volunteers
item.description: At least three foreigners have been killed fighting with Ukraine’s International Legion. One analyst said many would-be volunteers underestimated the danger from Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Malcolm Nance, a U.S. Navy veteran serving in Ukraine’s International Legion, contrasted the war in Ukraine with the American invasion of Iraq. “You’re the hunted now,” he said.

item.title: Bodies of Three Men Found in Bucha, Ukrainian Officials Say
item.description: A police chief said that victims’ bodies were discovered in a forest, and showed signs of mutilation.
item.dc:creator: Esha Ray
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies of civilians have been found in Bucha, Ukraine, ever since Russian troops pulled out in late March.

item.title: 4 Canadian Military Cadets Die After Car Plunges Into River
item.description: The men were set to graduate from the Royal Military College in a few weeks, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
